verses.text: Which they took up and used all help, undergirding the ship, fearing lest they should have fallen into Syrtis, and they strake sail, and so were carried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day when we were tossed with an exceeding tempest, they lightened the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the third day we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when neither sun nor stars in many days appeared, and no small tempest lay upon us, all hope that we should be saved, was then taken away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after long abstinence, Paul stood forth in the midst of them, and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened to me, and not have loosed from Candia: so should ye have gained this hurt and loss.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I exhort you to be of good courage: for there shall be no loss of any man’s life among you, save of the ship only.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there stood by me this night the Angel of God, whose I am, and whom I serve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saying, Fear not, Paul: for thou must be brought before Caesar: and lo, God hath given unto thee freely, all that sail with thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wherefore, Sirs, be of good courage: for I believe God, that it shall be so as it hath been told me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Howbeit, we must be cast into a certain Island.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the fourteenth night was come, as we were carried to and fro in the Adriatic sea about midnight, the shipmen deemed that some country approached unto them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And sounded, and found it twenty fathoms: and when they had gone a little further, they sounded again, and found fifteen fathoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then fearing lest they should have fallen into some rough places, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and wished that the day were come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now as the mariners were about to flee out of the ship, and had let down the boat into the sea under a color as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said unto the Centurion and the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat, and let it fall away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when it began to be day, Paul exhorted them all to take meat, saying, This is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried, and continued fasting, receiving nothing:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wherefore I exhort you to take meat: for this is for your safeguard: for there shall not an hair fall from the head of any of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when he had thus spoken, he took bread, and gave thanks to God in presence of them all, and brake it, and began to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then were they all of good courage, and they also took meat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now we were in the ship in all two hundred threescore and sixteen souls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, and cast out the wheat into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when it was day, they knew not the country, but they spied a certain creek with a bank, into the which they were minded (if it were possible) to thrust in the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when they had taken up the anchors, they committed the ship unto the sea, and loosed the rudder bonds, and hoisted up the main sail to the wind, and drew to the shore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when they fell into a place, where two seas met, they thrust in the ship: and the forepart stuck fast, and could not be moved, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them, when he had swam out, should flee away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Centurion willing to save Paul, stayed them from this counsel, and commanded that they that could swim, should cast themselves first into the sea, and go out to land:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the others, some on boards, and some on certain pieces of the ship: and so it came to pass, that they came all safe to land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when they were come safe, then they knew that the Isle was called Malta.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Barbarians showed us no little kindness, for they kindled a fire, and received us everyone, because of the present shower, and because of the cold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when Paul had gathered a number of sticks, and laid them on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and leaped on his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when the Barbarians saw the worm hang on his hand, they said among themselves, This man surely is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped the sea, yet Vengeance hath not suffered to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he shook off the worm into the fire, and felt no harm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Howbeit they waited when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly: but after they had looked a great while, and saw no inconvenience come to him, they changed their minds, and said, That he was a God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same quarters, the chief man of the Isle (whose name was Publius) had possessions: the same received us, and lodged us three days courteously.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so it was, that the father of Publius lay sick of the fever, and of a bloody flix: to whom Paul entered in, and when he prayed, he laid his hands on him, and healed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this then was done, others also in the Isle, which had diseases, came to him, and were healed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Which also did us great honor: and when we departed, they laded us with things necessary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now after three months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered in the Isle, whose badge was Castor and Pollux.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when we arrived at Syracuse, we tarried there three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And from thence we set a compass, and came to Rhegium: and after one day, the South wind blew, and we came the second day to Puteoli:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where we found brethren, and were desired to tarry with them seven days, and so we went toward Rome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And from thence when the brethren heard of us, they came to meet us at the Market of Appius, and at the three taverns, whom when Paul saw, he thanked God, and waxed bold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when we came to Rome, the Centurion delivered the prisoners to the general Captain: but Paul was suffered to dwell by himself with a soldier that kept him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the third day after, Paul calleth the chief of the Jews together, and when they were come, he said unto them, Men and brethren, though I have committed nothing against the people, or Laws of the fathers, yet was I delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who when they had examined me, would have let me go, because there was no cause of death in me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Jews spake contrary, I was constrained to appeal unto Caesar, not because I had ought to accuse my nation of.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this cause therefore have I called for you to see you, and to speak with you: for that hope of Israel’s sake, I am bound with this chain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said unto him, We neither received letters out of Judea concerning thee, neither came any of the brethren that showed or spake any evil of thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we will hear of thee what thou thinkest: for as concerning this sect, we know that everywhere it is spoken against.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when they had appointed him a day, there came many unto him into his lodging, to whom he expounded, testifying the kingdom of God, and persuading them those things that concern Jesus, both out of the Law of Moses, and out of the Prophets, from morning to night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And some were [persuaded] with the things which were spoken, and some believed not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore when they agreed not among themselves, they departed, after that Paul had spoken one word, to wit, Well spake the holy Ghost by Isaiah the Prophet unto our fathers,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saying, Go unto this people, and say, By hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand, and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the heart of this people is waxed fat, and their ears are dull of hearing, and with their eyes have they winked, lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their hearts, and should return that I might heal them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be it known therefore unto you, that this salvation of God is sent to the Gentiles, and they shall hear it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when he had said these things, the Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Paul remained two years full in an house hired for himself, and received all that came in unto him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with all boldness of speech, without let.
verses.speaker: Narrator
